question: Does bariatric surgery reduce the prevalence and severity of depression in patients after surgery compared with preoperative levels or non-surgical management? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Bariatric surgery was, however, consistently associated with postoperative decreases in the prevalence of depression (7 studies; 8%-74% decrease) and the severity of depressive symptoms (6 studies; 40%-70% decrease).
content.source_2: Across seven cohorts with follow-up extending beyond 18 months, postoperative depression became more common after bariatric surgery (prevalence rising by 8%–74%), and six studies reported 40%–70% worsening in depressive symptom severity.
content.source_3: Moderate-quality evidence supports an association between bariatric surgery and lower rates of depression postoperatively.
content.source_4: After adjustment for baseline psychiatric comorbidity and weight-loss trajectory, meta-analytic estimates from controlled cohorts showed no reduction in postoperative depression following bariatric surgery (pooled risk ratio ≈1.02; 95% CI 0.94–1.11), indicating no mental health benefit.
